title: Clean and Holy Living
shortSummary: Deuteronomy 14 outlines God's instructions to Israel regarding holiness through dietary laws, proper worship practices, and social responsibility. It emphasizes the distinctiveness of God's people as set apart by their obedience to His commands concerning clean and unclean animals, tithing, and care for the Levites and vulnerable in society.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period during the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Israelites
keyCharacters.description: God’s chosen people receiving instructions on holiness, dietary laws, and tithing to maintain covenant faithfulness.

keyCharacters.name: Levites
keyCharacters.description: The priestly tribe without land inheritance, dependent on tithes and offerings from the people.

keyCharacters.name: Strangers, Fatherless, and Widows
keyCharacters.description: Vulnerable groups within Israelite society who are provided for through the tithe and God’s commands.

definitions.definition: A people chosen and set apart by God for His special purposes, distinct from other nations.
One-tenth of one’s produce or increase given as an offering to God for the support of the Levites and worship.
Categories of animals defined by God’s law that determine what is permissible to eat and what is forbidden.

definitions.term: Seethe a Kid in His Mother's Milk
definitions.definition: A prohibition against cooking a young goat in its mother’s milk, understood as a command against mixing life and death or pagan rituals.

outline.heading: Call to Holiness and Prohibition of Pagan Mourning Practices
outline.description: God reminds Israel they are His holy children and forbids mourning customs like cutting or baldness marks, emphasizing their distinct identity.

outline.heading: Dietary Laws: Clean and Unclean Animals
outline.description: Detailed instructions on which animals are clean and may be eaten, and which are unclean and forbidden, underscoring obedience and separation from pagan nations.

outline.heading: Tithing Instructions and Worship Practices
outline.description: Command to tithe produce annually and consume it in the place God chooses, fostering reverence and communal worship.

outline.heading: Provision for Levites and the Needy
outline.description: Instructions to store tithes every three years to support Levites, strangers, orphans, and widows, highlighting God’s concern for social justice within the covenant community.

application: Live as a holy people set apart by God, avoiding worldly customs that dishonor Him.
Obey God’s commands regarding purity and holiness, including careful attention to what we consume as a reflection of spiritual obedience.
Practice faithful giving through tithing and generosity to support ministry and care for those in need within the church community.
Cultivate reverence for God by worshiping in the place He appoints and rejoicing in His provision.

keyVerses.text: For thou art an holy people unto the LORD thy God, and the LORD hath chosen thee to be a peculiar people unto himself, above all the nations that are upon the earth.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Israel’s unique identity as God’s chosen and holy people, foundational for understanding the call to obedience.

keyVerses.text: Ye shall not eat of any thing that dieth of itself: thou shalt give it unto the stranger that is in thy gates, that he may eat it; or thou mayest sell it unto an alien: for thou art an holy people unto the LORD thy God. Thou shalt not seethe a kid in his mother's milk.
keyVerses.significance: This verse connects holiness with ethical treatment of food and others, forbidding certain practices and emphasizing care for outsiders.

keyVerses.text: And thou shalt eat before the LORD thy God, in the place which he shall choose to place his name there, the tithe of thy corn, of thy wine, and of thine oil, and the firstlings of thy herds and of thy flocks; that thou mayest learn to fear the LORD thy God always.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches the importance of worshiping God with gratitude and reverence through the proper use of tithes.

keyVerses.text: And the Levite, (because he hath no part nor inheritance with thee,) and the stranger, and the fatherless, and the widow, which are within thy gates, shall come, and shall eat and be satisfied; that the LORD thy God may bless thee in all the work of thine hand which thou doest.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores God’s provision for those without inheritance and the blessing that comes from obedience to His commands on generosity.
